newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIA COALITION SAID POISED TO RAISE OIL PRICES.
newsitem.headline: INDIA COALITION SAID POISED TO RAISE OIL PRICES.

text.p: India's ruling coalition on Wednesday postponed a decision on whether to raise domestic petroleum prices but said it would soon have to increase prices despite stiff communist opposition.

The United Front's decision-making Steering Committee, deeply divided over how to control a mounting bill for oil subsidies, met for 30 minutes but for the fourth time in three months deferred the decision.
"It has not been resolved," Information Minister Jaipal Reddy, who is coalition spokesman, told reporters after the meeting.
But a senior coalition official said the 15-party United Front could not put off the decision for much longer as the government owes oil companies billions of dollars.
"There is no option but to increase prices which we would do shortly," the official, who asked not to be identified, told reporters.

"We will meet very soon to take a final view on oil prices," Reddy said. "There was a feeling today that the decision on oil prices could not be put off for too long and we should meet very soon, though no date could be fixed."
At the end of March, the government owed $4.3 billion to state oil firms, which sell some oil products such as kerosene to consumers at prices below world levels.
The government eventually reimburses the firms, but the bill has kept rising because of the gap between Indian and international prices.
Communists in the 15-party coalition have strongly opposed proposals to raise the prices of some products, arguing that the move would hurt the poor.
But critics of the communists' plan, which would slash import duties on crude oil and raise taxes on luxury cars, say it would not curtail the cost of subsidies.
The centre-left coalition raised oil prices shortly after assuming power in June 1996, saying the previous government led by the Congress party had failed to tackle the growing oil subsidy bill.
